Jinnō Shōtōki, pp. 164-165; ==Traditional history== Before he became the monarch, this prince's personal name (imina) was .Brown, p. 282; Varley, p. 164. Ninmyō was the second son of Emperor Saga and the Empress Tachibana no Kachiko. Ninmyō had nine Empresses, Imperial consorts, and concubines (kōi); and he had 24 Imperial sons and daughters.Brown, p. 283. ===Events of Ninmyō's life=== Ninmyō was Crown Prince for 10 years. * 6 January 823 (Kōnin 10, 4th month, 19th day): At age 14, Prince Masara is named Junna's heir. * 22 March 833 (Tenchō 10, 28th day of the 2nd month): In the 10th year of Emperor Junna's reign, the emperor abdicated. The succession (senso) was received by his adopted son. Masara- shinnō was the natural son of Emperor Saga, and therefore would have been Junna's nephew. Soon afterwards, Emperor Ninmyo is said to have acceded to the throne (sokui).Titsingh, p. 106; Brown, p. 283. This was confirmed in ceremonies.Varley, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no- Rei); retrieved 2011-12-23. * 838-839 (Jōwa 5-6): Diplomatic mission to Tang China headed by Fujiwara no Tsunetsugu.Sansom, George Bailey. (1958). A History of Japan to 1334, pp. 134-135; Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Fujiwara no Tsunetsugu" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 211. * 6 May 850 (Kashō 3, 21st day of the 3rd month): Emperor Ninmyō died at the age of 41.Adolphson, Mikael et al. (2007). Heian Japan, centers and peripheries, p. 23; Brown, p. 284 ===After his death=== Emperor Ninmyō is traditionally venerated at his tomb; the Imperial Household Agency designates , in Fushimi-ku, Kyoto, as the location of Ninmyō's mausoleum. Ninmyō was sometimes posthumously referred to as "the Emperor of Fukakusa," because that was the location of his tomb.Brown, p. 284; Varley, p. 165. ==Eras of reign== The years of Ninmyō's reign are identified by more than one era name (nengō).Titsingh, p. 106. * Tenchō (824-834) * Jōwa (834-848) * Kashō (848-851) ==Related pages== * Emperor of Japan * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese imperial family tree ==References== ==Other websites== * Hokusai: Poem #12, image of ceremonial event in Ninmyō's court Category:Emperors of Japan Category:810 births Category:850 deaths
